hawaiian_text: A hala ‘o Puali‘i i ka lawai‘a, i ia wā ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i hele ai me nā keiki he ‘umi  kumamāhiku i nā māla ‘uala a Puali‘i. ‘O ke kino o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ia wā, he kino ‘u‘uku loa, ‘elua  kapua‘i me ka hapa kona ki‘eki‘e, ‘a‘ole i pa‘a kona  ma‘i, e lewalewa ana nō. A hiki lākou i ua māla  ‘uala, kēnā akula ia i nā keiki, “E huhuki i ka pu‘e  me ka lau ‘uala ā pau loa i luna, mai waiho i kekahi e ulu ana.” Akā, maka‘u nō ua keiki, no laila, kāohi  mālie nō ma ka ‘uala, ‘a‘ohe huhuki i ka pu‘e.
llama4-scout-fireworks_translation: Puali‘i went fishing, and at that time Nāmakaokapāo‘o went with seventeen children to Puali‘i's taro patch. Nāmakaokapāo‘o's body at that time was very small, only two and a half feet tall, his illness not contained, and he was hanging on. When they arrived at that taro patch, he ordered the children, “Dig up all the taro shoots and leaves up high, don't leave any growing.” But the children were afraid, so they stayed quietly among the taro, and did not dig up the shoots.

This passage from Chapter 1, Paragraph 5, provides insights into the cultural, historical, and linguistic aspects of ancient Hawaiian society. 

#### Cultural Context
The passage illustrates a scene of everyday life in traditional Hawaii, specifically focusing on tasks related to food production and family or communal activities. The mention of "lawaia" (fishing) and "māla 'uala" (taro patch) highlights the importance of subsistence activities in Hawaiian culture. Taro was a staple crop in ancient Hawaii, crucial for survival and deeply embedded in Hawaiian spiritual and cultural practices.

The character of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, described as being very small in stature and ill, yet issuing commands, could imply a person of authority or spiritual significance. In traditional Hawaiian society, people with certain physical conditions or spiritual roles might be viewed with a mix of reverence and fear.

#### Linguistic Features
- **A hala ‘o Puali‘i i ka lawai‘a**: The use of "hala" to indicate Puali‘i's action of going fishing introduces a narrative technique common in Hawaiian storytelling, where actions and events are sequenced. "Hala" can be translated as "went" or "proceeded to," and its usage here sets the scene for the actions that follow.
- **I ia wā ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i hele ai me nā keiki he ‘umi kumamāhiku**: This sentence demonstrates the Hawaiian way of expressing time and action in narrative. The specification of "umi kumamāhiku" (seventeen) children accompanying Nāmakaokapāo‘o emphasizes the involvement of a considerable number of people, possibly implying a significant event or a communal activity.
- **‘O ke kino o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ia wā, he kino ‘u‘uku loa, ‘elua kapua‘i me ka hapa kona ki‘eki‘e**: The description of Nāmakaokapāo‘o's physical condition is detailed and vivid. The measurement of his height as "‘elua kapua‘i me ka hapa kona ki‘eki‘e" (two and a half feet) is culturally specific and historically relevant, providing a tangible image of his stature.
- **Akā, maka‘u nō ua keiki, no laila, kāohi mālie nō ma ka ‘uala, ‘a‘ohe huhuki i ka pu‘e**: The children's fear and their decision not to dig up the taro shoots reveal a dynamic of obedience and fear in response to Nāmakaokapāo‘o's commands. The use of "maka‘u" (fear) and "kāohi mālie" (staying quietly) in this context illustrates the emotional and behavioral responses of the characters.

#### Historical Significance
This passage can offer insights into the social and economic structures of pre-contact or early contact Hawaiian society. The emphasis on taro cultivation and fishing as primary activities underscores the self-sufficiency and resourcefulness of Hawaiian communities. Additionally, the portrayal of characters with special conditions or roles hints at the complex social hierarchies and the importance of spiritual or ceremonial leaders.

The detailed descriptions of actions, measurements, and emotional states also reflect a narrative style that values specificity and the sharing of knowledge through storytelling. This style is characteristic of Hawaiian oral traditions, where stories serve as a means of passing down history, cultural values, and practical knowledge.

Overall, this passage is a small but revealing window into the rich cultural landscape of ancient Hawaii, showcasing the language's expressiveness and the society's values and practices.

reference_translation: When Puali‘i left to go fishing, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  came with seventeen other children to the sweet  potato patches of Puali‘i. The body of   Nāmakaokapāo‘o at the time was very small, just  two and a half feet tall. His penis was not yet fully  grown and was dangling. When the kids got to the   sweet potato patches, Nāmakaokapāo‘o told the  other kids, “Rip out all of the sweet potato leaves. Don’t leave anything growing.” The children were  afraid and hesitated when they reached the  tubers, and they did not pull those out of the  mound.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 5:**• While Pua-li‘i was away fishing, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  came with 17 other children (perhaps all boys) to the  2 sweet potato patches. The reason they came to the  patches is not stated immediately, but it appears the  reason was to play. The 17 friends of Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o seem to represent the Hawaiian people as a  whole (or perhaps a group of individuals the  storyteller thinks poorly of) allegorically and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o seems to represent a progressive minded Hawaiian.  • Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is described at this point of the  story as very small, perhaps 2 feet tall, and that his  penis was not yet fully grown and dangling, likely  meaning he was not wearing a malo.  – The lack of a malo on a boy is descriptive of the  child being too young to wear one. In ‘Ai Kapu  culture, when boys are deemed to be physically  able for chores and work to help sustain the family,  they would go through rites to thrust them into an  age of productive work to help support the family  demonstrated by wearing a malo on a daily basis. It  was a sign of maturity (footnote: Pukui, Haertig, Lee (1972:114) “For the *keiki lewalewa*—usually shortened to *lewalewa*—was yet a “dangler.” A small boy, so young his penis dangled. As a dangler, he wore no  *malo* (loincloth) and he lived and ate with the women. For he was yet *poke‘o*, too young to join the men. ¶ When the little dangler became six or seven years old, his status  changed in one decisive ceremony. This was the *kā i mua*...”);  • The description of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o as a pre malo-wearing child contradicts the maturity and  leadership he demonstrates by his actions and  cognitive skills, where he tells his friends to destroy  the garden. The children demonstrate hesitancy and  destroy the vines and leaves of the sweet potatoes,  but do not dig out the tubers from under the ground. – This likely demonstrates a social rhetorical   commentary about or critique of the ‘Ai Kapu  culture as a whole, that it was worthy of   destruction, with its segregation of men and  women and emphasis on heirarchy, perhaps a  justification for abandoning the culture in 1819\.  The hesitancy of the children, and their depiction in this story as indecisive and timid could be a   Protestant Christian bias (post-1820). The idea of  not pulling out the sweet potato tubers from the  ground could represent not entirely eliminating the  Hawaiian people/culture in the Christian era (not a  complete genocide) despite the biases against the  ‘Ai Kapu;
